results.title: One a.m.
results.creator_credit: Lone Star Corporation, Van Beuren Corporation, Charles Chaplin and Henry P. Caulfield
results.brief_description: Charlie Chaplin at his slapstick best in the role of a drunk who unable to find his house keys climbs in through the window and ends up in a series of comic situations and confrontations. Cast also includes Albert Austin. No dialogue, music only.

results.title: One-sided triangle
results.creator_credit: David Evans, Sheppard Moscow Audio-Visual and Millbank Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Communicating”.
Concerned with effective communication within the working group or team. It spotlights the nature of behaviour and its causes when people meet in groups and points to the things that need to be done to maximise group effectiveness.

results.title: One
results.creator_credit: Little Red Filmhouse, Mark Tarnawsky and Robert Just
results.brief_description: Non-narrated film in which a young boy waiting for his father in an office complex becomes bored. He wanders off around the city and discovers a mime artist performing in the street.

results.title: Once were warriors (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Robin Scholes, Communicado, New Zealand Film Commission, Avalon Studios, New Zealand On Air and Lee Tamahori
results.brief_description: Based on Alan Duff’s controversial best seller, “Once Were Warriors” is an intense and powerful film that leaves audiences stunned with its uncompromising insight into the strength of Maori culture in the face of degrading urban ghettos and devastating family violence. Jake (Temuera Morrison) and Beth (Rena Owen) have been married 18 years and she still finds him irresistible. Jake is a muscular, handsome man who exudes an explosive sexual energy but spends most of the time at the pub, often proving his masculinity with his fists and regularly exploding into rages that leave terrible scars on Beth and his family.

results.title: Once upon Australia. River red
results.creator_credit: Klaus Toft, ABC-TV (Australia) and Nicholas Hilligoss
results.brief_description: ‘Once upon Australia’ examines our dinosaur past, vividly recreating giant goannas and marsupials using animation. This is a world where humans have little or no part. ‘River Red’ profiles the natural environment of one of Australia’s best known trees, the River Red Gum.

results.title: Once upon a wilderness
results.brief_description: Passages from an early pioneer’s journal illustrate the contrast between the American wilderness then, and the environment today. Shows how the wilderness is being decimated by construction and “progress”, often without thought. Emphasises the importance of attitudes. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Once upon a time, cinema [NTSC] = Nassereddin Shah, actor-e cinema
results.creator_credit: Masud Jafari Jozani and Mohsen Makhmalbaf
results.brief_description: Once again Iranian director Mohsen Makhmalbaf (The Marriage of the blessed, Gabbeh, Kandahar) has created an extraordinary piece of cinema with his tenth feature and first comedy. “Once upon a time, cinema” reflects on the history of Iranian cinema through the eyes of a Charlie Chaplin look-alike cinematographer whose main object in life is to bring the magic and fantasy of cinema to the Shah and his Persian court during the Qajar dynasty. Using excerpts from classic Iranian films, including “Gheisar (1969), “Still life” (1974), “Downpour” (1971) intercut with contemporary black and white footage, Makhmalbaf beautifully intertwines cinematic themes and genres from slapstick, melodrama and adventure to fantasy, surrealism and realism. The characters in the story consist of an eclectic mix, sometimes bordering on the bizarre, which only adds to the surreal tone of this intriguing and fascinating film. Cast includes Ezzatollah Entezami, Mahdi Hashemi, Mohammad Ali Keshavarz, Akbar Abdi, Dariush Arjomand, Faremah Motamed-Aria. (Awards: Istanbul; Karlovy Vary) In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Once upon a time, Beirut = Kan ya makan Beirut
results.creator_credit: Balcon Productions, Aleph Productions and Jocelyne Saab
results.brief_description: Two young women, distraught over the destruction of Beirut and curious to get beneath the romantic, mythical stereotypes of the city in its heyday, visit a reclusive and eccentric film collector. In an abandoned theatre they mine his huge archive of films, entering a vast cinematic history of Beirut from the silent era, through the French-directed films of the 1930s, films of the 1960s by Arab filmmakers, to the large scale American studio films of the 1970s. Drawing on hundreds of excerpts, Saab portrays the cinematic fantasies of Beirut that proliferated in the prewar era. From temptresses to spies to villains, Beirut was a playground in which consistently fantastic narratives took place. The two young women literally enter these films. Appearing as characters in scenes they comment on the narratives from a contemporary perspective, attempting to reconcile this imagery with the war-savaged Beirut of today. A historical mapping of the cinematic landscape of Lebanon that reveals an explicit interest in memory, ‘Once Upon a Time, Beirut’ actively seeks to understand how media representations have manipulated the identity of this complex city. In French and Arabic with English subtitles.
